abstract.p: Background and purpose: The objective of this article is to create guidelines for education interventions in the management of patients (>18 years old) with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Methods: The Ottawa Methods Group identified and synthesized evidence from comparative controlled trials using Cochrane Collaboration methods. The group then formed an expert panel, which developed a set of criteria for grading the strength of the evidence and the recommendation. Patient-important outcomes were determined through consensus, provided that these outcomes were assessed with validated and reliable scales.
Results: Sixty-four positive recommendations of clinical benefit (35 of A level and 29 of C+ level) were developed for patient education in RA.
Discussion and conclusion: For the management of rheumatoid arthritis, the use of patient education is recommended by the Ottawa Panel.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disease involving inflammation of the joints, leading to joint pain, swelling, stiffness and possible deformity. It is an extremely disabling disease that reduces physical function and health-related quality of life; even with appropriate drug therapy, 30–50% are too disabled to work five years after disease onset.1 As a result of its biological effects, RA incurs significant direct costs, such as health care expenses, indirect costs such as loss of productivity due to morbidity and costs due to decreased life expectancy.2 It is one of the most prevalent chronic conditions, found in approximately 1% of the adult population,3 and affects more women than men.4 The incidence of RA is greatest among those aged 40 to 60 years.

Despite the fact that significant progress has been made in the clinical management of RA over the last decade, there is an urgent need for rehabilitation specialists to provide the most efficient and effective treatments for their clients. Recent cutbacks in the health care system have magnified the need for appropriate and effective treatments. Although most of the clinical guidelines recommend patient education as part of the intervention in RA,5, 6 no details are given to the clinicians or patients as to how education should be given and what it should include. The goal of this article is to present evidence-based clinical practice guidelines (EBCPGs) which will allow RA patients to optimally benefit from their rehabilitation programmes.

The objective of this article is to develop clinical guidelines based on a systematic review for interventions in rehabilitative care with adult individuals suffering from rheumatoid arthritis (RA). These clinical guidelines will focus on the efficacy of patient education interventions currently used in the field of rehabilitation sciences. These interventions needed to be systematized to assist clinicians in physiotherapy and occupational therapy to guide optimal clinical decision-making when caring with individuals with rheumatoid arthritis.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study incorporated methods similar to those developed for the Philadelphia Panel for EBCPGs7 and those of the Ottawa Panel on therapeutic exercises and electrotherapy in RA.8, 9 The Ottawa Methods Group (OMG) consisted of nine methodologists experienced in the development of EBCPG guidelines. The OMG requested that professional associations caring for those with RA nominate panellists both familiar with EBCPGs and experienced in clinical RA management. Of those nominated, the OMG chose nine clinical specialty experts as panellists, included a rheumatologist, a physiatrist, a physician, a family physician, three physical therapists, an occupational therapist, and a patient with RA. These nine experts and the OMG comprised the Ottawa Panel. The OMG assembled a research and support staff that consisted of persons with expertise in meta-analysis, rheumatology rehabilitation interventions, research methods and the development and assessment of EBCPGs.

In order to systematically screen the studies, the OMG established a priori inclusion criteria (Table 1) for the study designs, subject samples, interventions and outcomes. The inclusion criteria enabled research staff to identify the most relevant articles as evidence of the effectiveness of patient education on RA. The inclusion criteria were later reviewed by the OMG to ensure that the resulting study selection was reproducible and systematic. This a priori protocol guided separate systematic literature reviews for each intervention. Material was reviewed by the research staff and evidence tables were generated and distributed one month prior to the consensus meeting to the Ottawa Panel members to serve as the basis for making recommendations.

sec.title: Literature search
sec.p: A structured literature search was developed by the library scientist, based on the sensitive search strategy for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) recommended by the Cochrane Collaboration and modifications proposed by Haynes and colleagues.10 The Cochrane Collaboration method is used to minimize bias through a systematic approach to the literature search, study selection, and data extraction and synthesis. Being an a priori search, it was focused around the condition and interventions, rather than the outcomes (Appendix 1). For this reason, we did not have control over the outcomes chosen by the authors.

The search strategy was expanded to identify other comparative controlled, case-control, cohort, and nonrandomized studies. The library scientist searched the electronic databases of MEDLINE, EMBASE, Current Contents, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health (CINAHL), SUMSearch, and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register up to June 2010. Additionally, the registries of the Cochrane Field of Rehabilitation and Related Therapies, the Cochrane Musculoskeletal Group, the Physiotherapy Evidence Database (PEDro), and the University of Ottawa EBCPGs Web site were searched. The reference lists of all of the included trials were searched for relevant studies and content experts were contacted for additional studies.

sec.title: Type of intervention
sec.p: Patient education included different approaches such as cognitive-behaviour, behaviour modification and different strategies such as health education, social support techniques and combinations of these strategies. Teaching was home or health-centre based and was performed in groups or on a one-on-one basis. Group treatments were professionally led. Comparison interventions that were acceptable included traditional care, no education treatment (including waiting list and geographically-distant controls), reduced comprehensiveness of education (e.g. reduced number of sessions, lack of follow-up after educational sessions common to both controls and experimental groups, receipt of only educational summary), or use of educational literature for self-management. Concurrent therapies (such as exercise and treatments) were accepted only if they were provided to both the experimental and control groups. Studies in which patients served as their own controls were excluded. No limitations based on methodological quality were imposed a priori, though the quality of comparative controlled studies was considered when grading the recommendations resulting from our analysis. Head-to-head studies (comparison of two active interventions) were generally rejected because the goal was to make a recommendation about a specific intervention. Head-to-head comparisons of teaching versus didactic information and participatory versus didactic education studies were included as this was determined relevant to RA rehabilitation practice.

sec.title: Type of study designs
sec.p: All original comparative controlled studies that evaluated specific educational interventions with patients with RA were included. This included RCTs, controlled clinical trials (CCTs), cohort studies, and case-control studies. Crossover studies were included, and to avoid potential confounders, data from only the first part of the study (pre-crossover) were included. Excluded studies were those with an uncontrolled cohort design (no comparison group), case series design, and eligible studies with dropout rates greater than 20% or a sample size less than five patients per group. Where full text articles were unavailable, even from the authors, abstracts were excluded because they were unable to furnish sufficient data for analysis. Trials published in languages other than English and French were excluded due to the time and cost involved in translation.

sec.title: Type of participants
sec.p: The studies included were those with samples of adult patients (18 years of age and older) diagnosed with RA according to the criteria of the 1987 American Rheumatism Association (ARA). Acute and chronic RA were both included in the different clinical trials studied, sometimes appearing in the same trial. However, wherever possible, the recommendations specify whether the intervention is appropriate for chronic or acute conditions. The recommendations also include classification of functional capacity in patients with RA described as: (1) complete functional capacity with ability to carry out all usual duties without handicaps; (2) functional capacity adequate to conduct normal activities despite the handicap of discomfort or limited mobility of one or more joints; (3) functional capacity adequate to perform only a few or none of the duties of usual occupation of or of self-care; or (4) largely or completely incapacitated, with the patient bed-ridden or wheelchair-bound, permitting little or no self-care.12 In cases of recommendations where disease severity or functional severity are not mentioned, it is because the trial on which the recommendation was based did not indicate degree of severity (Appendix 2).

Studies were excluded if they contained samples of patients with RA concurrently having back or neck problems, due to the numerous and varied associated signs and symptoms of these conditions. In addition, spine disorders were not considered for inclusion because the Philadelphia Panel had recently developed guidelines for back and neck pain.13, 14 Further exclusion criteria included studies of patients who had recently had surgery or who had one of the following conditions: (1) other rheumatologic or musculoskeletal problems, such as tendonitis, bursitis, or fractures; (2) major medical problems that could interfere with the rehabilitation process or incapacitate functional status; or (3) psychiatric conditions. Studies of subjects without known pathology or impairments were also excluded. Studies of patients with mixed arthritic conditions were excluded unless the mixed conditions were RA and osteoarthritis (OA) and only then if the case mix contained at least 75% patients with RA. Further inclusion and exclusion criteria are given in Table 1.

sec.title: Type of outcomes
sec.p: To measure effectiveness, validated and reliable outcomes were selected based on the recommendations of the conference on Outcome Measures for Rheumatoid Arthritis Clinical Trials (OMERACT)15 and by the theoretical framework for rehabilitation application.16 The a priori outcomes were selected according to the Philadelphia Panel recommendations,7 as well as from the Canadian Physiotherapy Association’s ‘Physical Rehabilitation Outcome Measures (PROM II)’17 and RIFSSSO’s ‘Répertoire des outils d’évaluation en français pour la réadaptation’.18 Outcomes that were psychosocial (e.g. depression) and physiological (e.g. cardiopulmonary capacity) were excluded. Further details are found in Table 1.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: Two independent reviewers appraised the studies of the literature search and created an individual list of all the articles in the database with a reason for their inclusion or exclusion. In cases of uncertainty about an article after reading the abstract, the reviewers read the article in full before making the determination. Where there were inconsistent findings, the two independent lists of articles were checked for inclusion/exclusion reasons by a senior reviewer who is an expert in RA. In the next stage of inclusion/exclusion determination, the pair of reviewers retrieved the articles initially screened for inclusion and assessed the full articles for final inclusion or exclusion from the study.

sec.title: Data extraction and methodological quality assessment
sec.p: Using pre-determined data extraction forms, each of the reviewers independently extracted data on the population characteristics, details of the interventions, trial design, allocation concealment, and outcomes. Methodological quality was assessed using the Jadad Scale, a five-point scale reported to be valid and reliable that assigns two points each for randomization and double-blinding and one point for description of withdrawals.19 A Jadad scale score below 3 (< 3) will be considered as being of low methodological quality, while a Jadad score of 3 or more (≥ 3) will be classified as high quality study. The Ottawa Panel approved to the inclusion of CCSs that had a score of < 3 if they met the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Consequently, the Ottawa Panel focused more on the randomization component of the Jadad scale. Quality scores from the Jadad scale were used to interpret the results and, if any discrepancies in the data extraction and scoring of methodological quality occurred, the leading methodologist was consulted to resolve such disparity. Studies that failed to successfully meet the methodological criteria illustrated in the inclusion and exclusion table (Table 2) and that were categorized by the Ottawa Panel as poor methodological quality trials were reassigned to the list of excluded studies. The Cochrane Collaboration methodology was used to generate the figures.20

sec.p: Clinical improvement was defined as 15% improvement compared to a control, based on previous work relating to musculoskeletal rehabilitation21 as well as consensus.7 For dichotomous data, the relative percentage of improvement was taken to be the difference in the percentage of improvement between the intervention and the control groups.22

sec.title: Reviewing the guidelines
sec.p: The guidelines were externally reviewed by practitioners in order to assess clinical usefulness and ensure relevance of the findings.23 Feedback was solicited from five practitioners who were currently working with patients with RA. These practitioners, selected from clinical settings in Ottawa and Toronto regions, included a physical therapist, an occupational therapist, a physiatrist, a family physician and a rheumatologist. The practitioners were asked to comment on four questions for each guideline: whether the recommendation was clear, whether they agreed with the recommendation, whether they felt that the literature search on patient education was relevant and complete, and whether the results of the trials in the guidelines were interpreted according to their understanding of the data.

sec.title: Literature search
sec.p: The literature search identified 118 articles potentially relevant based on the selection criteria for RA only. Of these, 28 articles24–51 met the selection criteria for patient education interventions and were included (Table 3). The other 90 studies52–141 were excluded (results not shown) for various reasons: 28 studies53–55, 57, 61, 74, 75, 78, 84, 89, 90, 109–113, 115, 117, 118, 120–122, 125, 127, 129, 133, 139, 141 were not appropriate PE interventions; there was a < 75% proportion of RA patients56, 62, 66, 72, 76, 77, 80, 81, 83, 93, 95, 97, 100, 101, 104, 105, 107, 131 or unconfirmed diagnosis71 in 19 studies; nine studies60, 68, 70, 86, 87, 99, 103, 134, 135 were literature review; 15 studies did not have sufficient data studies52, 56, 69, 73, 79, 88, 106, 108, 126, 127, 130, 136, 138 or a had a drop-out rate94 greater than 20%; seven58, 82, 92, 96, 98, 132, 140 studies had no control group; outcomes could not be used in five studies;64, 85, 91, 102, 119 six63, 65, 114, 116, 124, 137 were not clinical trials, and two67, 123 others were published in a language other than English or French.

sec.title: Methodological quality
sec.p: Out of the 24 included RCTs, there were five studies28, 29, 31, 43, 44 with a Jadad score of 3 which was of higher methodological quality (≥ 3). The remaining RCTs were of lower quality (< 3): 16 RCTs 24,25,27,30,32,34,36–38, 40–42, 45, 47, 49, 50 had a score of 2/5, two RCTs26, 51 had a score of 1/5, and one RCT39 had a score of 0/5. All four CCTs were of lower quality with two having a score of 1/533, 35 while the other two CCTs46, 48 had a score of 0/5. No study received the point for ‘double-blind’.

sec.title: Summary of trials
sec.p: Twenty four trials (N = 3,716)24–51 measured the effectiveness of patient education for people diagnosed with RA. Eight trials examined the effectiveness of a cognitive behavioural programme.31, 33, 35, 42–44, 49, 50 Fourteen trials assessed the effectiveness of an educational-behavioural programme.27–30, 32, 35–39, 41, 45, 47, 48 Four trials examined the effectiveness of a self-instructional education programme.24, 25, 40, 51 One study measured the effectiveness of educational support groups,46 while the remaining trial examined the effectiveness of an intervention involving the combination of education, exercise and medication26 (Table 3; Appendix 2).

In the trials of cognitive behavioural programmes,31, 33, 35, 42–44, 49, 50 a grade of A was demonstrated for pain relief (Figure 1; see Appendix 2),43, 50 compliance50 and arthritis knowledge.50 A grade of C+ was demonstrated for early morning stiffness,31 compliance,33 quality of life,50 and pain relief.50 A grade of C was demonstrated for pain relief,31, 44 fatrigue,31 perceived health,31 RA self-effiacy,31, 50 self-efficacy (end of treatment),31 psychological distress,31 arthritis helplessness,31, 43 quality of life,35, 42, 50 functional status,49 and endurance.50 A grade of D was demonstrated for quality of life.35 A grade of D+ was demonstrated for functional status,31 quality of life,42 and pain relief.44

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The Ottawa Panel brought to light a significant number of EBCPGs on patient education for rheumatoid arthritis. Five different education programmes were identified: cognitive-behavioural programme, educational-behavioural programme, self-instructional education, combined educational programme and support group as well as combined education programme, exercise and medication intake.

Strong evidence (Grades A: n = 35 and C+: n = 29) revealed that each of the five patient education programmes identified is an appropriate intervention to treat RA patients, especially to reduce disease activity, morning stiffness, pain intensity, and to increase grip force, endurance, exercise compliance, to develop knowledge on the illness, to improve functional status, joint protection, energy conversation, self-efficacy, patient as well as physician global assessment, to enhance psychological well-being and quality of life (QOL). These recommendations (Grades A and C+) had both clinical importance and statistical significance or clinical importance only (Grade C+). Among the remaining recommendations, 96 were graded C, 73 were graded D, and 12 were graded D+.

The results of this paper show that a wide variety of educational programmes can be adopted by health care professionals. Among the articles that lead to EBCPGs recommendations, most of the studies were group educational programmes which include a handout, workbook, or leaflet given to participants.27–29, 32, 33, 35, 37, 39, 43, 46, 48 Content of the interventions usually covered the pathophysiology of RA, joint protection, rest and positioning, pain management, energy conservation, exercises and medication. An example of the content and handout given to participants is the leaflet produced by the Arthritis and Rheumatism Council (ARC) used in Barlow et al.24 and Hammond et al.27

The sessions were generally given by a combination of health care professionals and other hospital staff such as physicians (e.g. rheumatologist or generalist), occupational therapists, physiotherapists, nurses, clinician psychologists, and social workers.25–29, 33, 34, 44–46 There was less variability for the number of sessions as well as for the duration of the education programmes. On average, the studies that lead to recommendations were given about four sessions, for a total of length of eight hours.

However, there is a trend to be explored in future studies. The outcomes obtained seem to be in relation to the nature of the educational programme and its specific components. For instance, educational programmes which involved exercises and joint protection instructions seems to have a positive impact on joint protection as well as those which involved self-instructional programmes seem to produce a positive impact on self-efficacy, etcetera. The clinical goal setting seemed to be a key element and a prerequisite to implement a successful patient education programme.142

Using systematic review procedures, we were able to extend the findings of Riemsma et al.143, 144 to include studies up to 2010, and we were able to identify the demonstrated impact of these programmes exclusively on patients with RA. Both systematic reviews revealed that educational programmes lead to a significant effect on pain relief when applied during three to 12 weeks, especially when it is measured using a 10cm visual analogue scale (VAS). However, this effect seems to have no retention effect at longer term.

Additionally, the Ottawa Panel recommendations are in concordance with other clinical practice guidelines;145 related to the efficacy of patient education for the management of RA, especially to improve pain, physical activity level, self-efficacy and quality of life, joint protection, and conservation of energy.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The primary limitation to this study was the lack of correlation among included programmes. While we were able to generally group studies according to the broad objectives of treatment, the studies within each category varied in regards to length of programme, primary and secondary outcomes, method of delivery, and timing of follow-up. In addition, the majority of included RCTs were of low methodological quality. Since some of the studies are not recent, updated research using better methodology is necessary. Although several of the studies had a description of methods and interventions, more details would be needed to replicate the education programmes.

sec.title: Implications for practice
sec.p: Evidence was found by the Ottawa Panel that patient education is an effective intervention to improve the quality of life and significantly change behaviour to have an impact on the different challenges among the population with RA. Since EBCPGs recommendations were based on a wide variety of education programmes, clinicians and multidisciplinary teams have the flexibility to develop their own programmes related to a specific clinical goal setting and still expect to have significant improvement on outcomes. Furthermore, this systematic review supports group education, which could help maximize the time spent by health care professionals to educate RA patients and overcome barriers (e.g. limited staffing and clinical time, funding for programme costs) to implement these programmes in clinical settings.142

Patients with early RA.

sec.title: Self-instructional education
sec.p: Education material versus control (traditional care), level I (1 RCT, n = 216, low quality47): grade A (clinically important) for improved compliance (physical exercises [min/week]) at follow-up one month and at follow-up 19 months, for improved endurance (endurance exercises [min]) at follow-up 19 months, and for improved disease activity (swollen joint count [0–46]) at follow-up 19 months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: mobility, dexterity [0–10], pain [0–10]) at follow-up one month, for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: physical activity [0–10]) at follow-ups one month and 19 months, for improved walking speed (10m walking time [min]) at follow-up one month, for increased force (grip force [mm Hg]) at follow-up one month, for improved arthritis knowledge [10–100]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved disease activity (swollen joint count [0–46]) at follow-up one month, for pain relief (Ritchie articular index [0–75]) at follow-up one month, and for improved self-efficacy (ASE: function [10–100], other symptoms [10–100]) at follow-up one month, grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control [traditional care]) for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: mobility, dexterity [0–10], pain [0–10]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved functional status (M-HAQ: disability [0–3]) at follow-ups one month and 19 months, for improved mobility (walking speed, 10m walking time [min]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved endurance (endurance exercises [min]) at follow-up one month, for increased force (grip force [mm Hg]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved arthritis knowledge (10–100) at follow-up one month, for pain relief (Ritchie articular index [0–75]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved self-efficacy (ASE: pain [10–100]) at follow-up one month, and for improved self-efficacy (ASE: function [10–100], other symptoms [10–100]) at follow-up 19 months. Patients with RA, unspecified disease duration.

Coordinated educational material plus passport versus control (traditional care), level I (1 RCT, n = 216, low quality47): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit without statistical significance) for improved compliance (physical exercises [min/week]) at follow-up 19 months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: dexterity [0–10]) at follow-up one month, for increased force (grip force [mm Hg]) at follow-up one month, for improved disease activity (swollen joint count [0–46]) at follow-ups one month and 19 months, for improved self-efficacy (ASE: pain [10–100]) at follow-up one month, and for improved self-efficacy (ASE: other symptoms [10–100]) at follow-up one month; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control (traditional care)) for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: physical activity [0–10]) at follow-ups one month and 19 months, for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: pain [0–10]) at follow-up nine months, for improved functional status (M-HAQ: disability [0–3]) at follow-up one month and 19 months, for improved walking speed (10m walking time [min]) at follow-up one month, for improved endurance (endurance exercises [min]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved arthritis knowledge [0–100] at follow-ups one month and 19 months, for pain relief (Ritchie articular index [0–75]) at follow-up one month, for improved self-efficacy (ASE: function [10–100]) at follow-ups one month and 19 months, and for improved self-efficacy (ASE: other symptoms [10–100]) at follow-up 19 months; grade D+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated favouring control [traditional care] without statistical significance) for improved quality of life (Dutch AIMS: dexterity [0–10]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved compliance (physical exercises [min/week]) at follow-up one month, for improved walking speed (10m walking time [min]) at follow-up 19 months, for improved endurance (endurance exercises [min]) at follow-up one month, for increased force (grip force [mm Hg]) at follow-up 19 months, for pain relief (Ritchie articular index [0–75]) at follow-up 19 months, and for improved self-efficacy (ASE: pain [10–100] at follow-up 19 months. Patients with RA, whose RA diagnoses met the revised ARA criteria, between ages of 20 and 70, consulted providers of health care from two or more disciplines during the previous six months.

Self-instructional education versus control (not received leaflet), level I (1 RCT, n = 84, low quality24): grade A (clinically-important benefits) for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score) at end of treatment three weeks and at follow-up six months; grade C+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated without statistical significance) for improved self-efficacy (ASE: pain) at end of treatment three weeks; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for pain relief (VAS [0–10cm]) at end of treatment three weeks, at follow-up six months, for improved self-efficacy (ASE: pain) at follow-up six months, and for improved self-efficacy (ASE: other symptoms) at end of treatment three weeks and at follow-up six months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Self-instruction only versus control (no intervention), level I (1 RCT, n = 53, low quality40): grade A (clinically-important benefit) for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–40]) at follow-up four months; grade C+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated without statistical significance) for pain relief (VAS [0–10cm]) at follow-up four months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Self-instruction plus practice versus control (no intervention), level I (1 RCT, n = 53, low quality40): grade A (clinically-important benefit) for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–40]) at follow-up four months; grade C+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated without statistical significance) for pain relief (VAS [0–10cm]) at follow-up four months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Self-instruction plus practice and contracting versus control (no intervention), level I (1 RCT, n = 53, low quality40): grade A (clinically-important benefit of self-instruction plus practice and contracting versus control [no intervention]) for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–40]) at follow-up four months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for pain relief (VAS [0–10]) at follow-up four months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Self-instruction only versus self-instruction plus practice, level I (1 RCT, n = 53, low quality40): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit without statistical significance) for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–40]) at follow-up four months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for pain relief (VAS [0–10]) at follow-up four months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Self-instruction plus practice versus self-instruction plus practice and contracting, Level I (1 RCT, n = 53, low quality40): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit without statistical significance) for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–40]) at follow-up four months and for pain relief (VAS [0–10cm]) at follow-up four months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Community-based education versus control (no education), level I (1 RCT, n = 150, low quality25): grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved disease activity (morning stiffness) at end of treatment six weeks; for pain relief (VAS [0–100mm]) at end of treatment six weeks, for pain relief (tender joint count) at end of treatment six weeks and at follow-up three months, for improved self-efficacy (ASE: pain and other symptoms) at end of treatment six weeks and at follow-up three months, for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–31]) at end of treatment six weeks and at follow-up three months, and for improved disease activity (morning stiffness) at follow-up three months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control (no education) for pain relief (VAS [0–100mm]) at end of treatment six weeks and Follow-up (FU) three months, and for increased force (grip force [mm Hg]) at end of treatment six weeks. Patients with RA (referral for a physical therapy intervention, diagnosis confirmed by a physician), disease onset after age 18, first referral to consultation, ability to read, write and speak English, ability to understand the purpose of the study and provide informed consent, consent four or more visits of three hours or more from a CTS physical therapist, available for follow-up for the full length of the study, at least three of 12 potential.

Computer based education versus control (no intervention), level I (1 RCT, n = 36, low quality51): grade A (clinically-important benefit) for improved psychological well-being (number of patients with improved joint protection) at end of treatment one month.

sec.title: Education programme combined with group support
sec.p: Group education (cognitive-behavioural) and booklet versus control (no education programme), level I (1 RCTs, n = 83, high quality43): grade A (clinically-important benefits) for pain relief (Figure 1) (VAS [0–100]) at end of treatment 12 months;43 grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved helplessness (arthritis helplessness index [AHI]) at end of treatment 12 months.43 Patients diagnosed with RA.43

sec.title: Education programme combined with exercise
sec.p: OT plus usual rheumatology care versus contro (usual care), level I (1 RCT, n = 326, low quality30): grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for pain relief (VAS [0–100mm]) at follow-up six months, for improved quality of life (AIMS2: satisfaction with health [0–10]) at follow-up six and12 months, for improved disease activity (swollen joint count [0–28]) at follow-up 12 months, for improved disease activity (morning stiffness [min]) at follow-up 24 months, for increased force (grip force [kg]) at follow-up 12 months, and for improved self-efficacy (total self-efficacy) at follow-up six months and follow-up 12 months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring contro [usual care]) for pain relief (VAS [0–100], tender joint count [0–28]) at follow-up 12 months and follow-up 24 months, for improved quality of life (AIMS2: physical function [0–10]) at follow-up six months, follow-up 12 months, and follow-up 24 months, for improved quality of life (AIMS2: satisfaction with health [0–28]) at follow-up six months and 24 months, for improved disease activity (swollen joint count [0–28]) at follow-up 12 months and follow-up 24 months, for improved disease activity (morning stiffness [min]) at follow-up six and 12 months, for improved functional status (HAQ [0–3]) at follow-up 12 months and follow-up 24 months, for improved physical function (Jensen hand function test [sec]) at follow-up six months, follow-up 12 months, and follow-up 24 months, for increased force (grip force [kg]) at follow-up six months and follow-up 24 months, and for improved self-efficacy (total self-efficacy) at follow-up 24 months. Patients with RA by a consultant rheumatologist within the past 2.5 years, recruited from hospitals in the former North Thames Regional Health Authority, aged over 18 years, required active medical treatment, had no or minimal OT previously; and could speak and read English adequately to complete assessments.

Group education (educational-behavioural) versus control (no education), level II (1 CCT, n = 45, low quality48): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated without statistical significance) for improved psychological well-being (achieve health outcomes [1–10]; Siu, 2004) and management of disease in general (1–10; Siu, 2004) at follow-up nine months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved psychological well-being (self-rated health [0–5]; Siu, 2004)) at follow-up nine months, for pain relief (pain and physical discomfort [0–100]; Siu, 2004) at follow-up nine months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated) for improved quality of life (energy and fatigue [0–5]; Siu, 2004) at follow-up nine months, for improved psychological well-being (health care utilization [0–5]; Siu, 2004) at follow-up nine months; grade D+ clinically-important benefit demonstrated favouring control (no education) without statistical significance for improved functional status (performance self-management behaviours [1–10]; Siu, 2004) at follow-up nine months. All the participants of this study had RA and were new to the service of the community rehabilitation network.

sec.title: Education programme combined with self-instruction
sec.p: Group education and workbook (educational-behavioural) versus control (no intervention), level I (1 RCT, n = 135, low quality27): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated without statistical significance) for improved self-efficacy (ASE) at end of treatment three months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for pain relief (VAS [0–100mm]) at end of treatment three months, for pain relief (tender joint count) at end of treatment three months, for increased force (grip force [mm Hg]) at end of treatment three months, for improved mobility (Hand JAM [Hammond, Lincoln et al., 1999]) at end of treatment three months, and for improved functional status (HAQ [0–3]) at follow-up three months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control [no education]) for improved functional status (HAQ [0–3]) at end of treatment three months; grade D+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated favouring control [no intervention] without statistical significance) for functional status (HAQ [0–3]) at end of treatment three months. Patients with RA and wrist and/or MCP involvement, no other medical condition affecting hand function, some restriction in ability to perform daily activities and recreational activities.

Education with exercise and medication versus control (brochure only, no education), level I (1 RCT, n = 60, low quality26) (Brus, 1998): grade A (clinically-important benefits) for improved joint protection at follow-up three months; grade C+ (clinically-important benefit demonstrated without statistical significance) for improved energy conservation at follow-up three months, at follow-up six months, and at follow-up 12 months, for improved endurance (endurance activities) at follow-up three months and at follow-up 12 months, and for improved joint protection at follow-up six months and at follow-up 12 months, for improved functional status (exercise) at follow-up three and 12 months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved endurance (endurance activities) at follow-up six months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control [brochure only, no education]) for improved functional status (exercise) at follow-up six months. Patients suffering from RA, following the ACR criteria, for less than three years, six or more painful joints and three or more swollen joints.

Teaching versus participatory education, level I (1 RCT, n = 28, low quality45): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit without statistical significance) for pain relief (Richey-camp articular index) at end of treatment three months, for improved quality of life (number of patients with improved rest during activity) at end of treatment three months, for improved quality of life (number of patients with improved HAQ fatigue) at end of treatment three months, for improved functional status (number of patients improved in physical activity) at end of treatment three months, and for improved functional status (number of patients improved index of physical activity) at end of treatment three months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved functional status (HAQ [0–3]) at end of treatment three months, and for pain relief (number of patients with improved HAQ: pain) at end of treatment three months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control [participatory education] for improved arthritis knowledge (knowledge score [0–34]) at end of treatment three months. Patients 18 years old or older with a diagnosis of adult RA, probable as defined by the American Rheumatism Association criteria or classical RA for at least one year, not hospitalized, participating voluntarily with permission from primary physician.

Group education (educational-behavioural) and handbook versus control (no education programme), level I (1 RCT, n = 96, low quality36): grade C+ (clinically-important benefit without statistical significance) for improved functional status (HAQ: impairment) at follow-up 12 months; grade C (no benefit demonstrated) for improved joint protection at follow-up three months and at follow-up 12 months, for pain relief (VAS [0–100mm]) at follow-up six months and improved functional status (compliance to exercise) at follow-up 12 months; grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control [no education programme] for pain relief (VAS [0–100mm]) at follow-up three months and at follow-up 12 months, and for improved functional status [compliance to exercise] at follow-up three months, for improved functional status (HAQ: impairment [Lindroth, 1997]) at follow-up 12 months. Patients diagnosed with RA.

Group education (educational-behavioural) versus control (no education programme), n = , level I (1 RCT, low quality37): grade A (clinically-important benefits) for improved quality of life (AIMS physical function [0–10]) at the end of treatment eight months,37 for psychological status (AIMS psychological [0–10]) at the end of treatment eight months,37 disease progression (AIMS symptoms [0–10]) at the end of treatment eight months,37 for social status (AIMS social interaction [1–10]) at the end of the treatment eight months,37 for physical ability (AIMS work [0–10]) at the end of treatment eight months,37 and for improved functional status (HAQ [0–3]) at the end of treatment eight months;37 grade D (no benefit demonstrated but favouring control [no education programme] for pain relief (VAS [0–100]) at the end of treatment eight months.37 Patients diagnosed with RA, aged 18–65 years old, presented no variations in drug therapy in the six months before trial, did not present severe disability that seriously compromised independence in activities of daily living.37
